title: Part (a)(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how eutrophication negatively impacts waterways.

· Eutrophication results in low dissolved oxygen (because bacteria consume oxygen as they eat animal waste that runs off into waterways from the concentrated animal feedlots/dead algal blooms resulting from nutrients in animal waste) in the waterways, which can kill aquatic organisms.

The response describes how eutrophication negatively impacts waterways.

· Eutrophication results in low dissolved oxygen (because bacteria consume oxygen as they eat animal waste that runs off into waterways from the concentrated animal feedlots/dead algal blooms resulting from nutrients in animal waste) in the waterways, which can kill aquatic organisms.

title: Part (a)(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a realistic solution to prevent eutrophication of waterways near CAFOs, such as any of the following.

· Switch to grass-fed operations

· Eat lower on food chain/eat plant matter rather than beef

· Plant buffers of vegetation

· Construct physical barriers/retention ponds

The response proposes a realistic solution to prevent eutrophication of waterways near CAFOs, such as one of the following.

· Switch to grass-fed operations

· Eat lower on food chain/eat plant matter rather than beef

· Plant buffers of vegetation

· Construct physical barriers/retention ponds

title: Part (a)(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not justify the solution with an additional environmental benefit, such as any of the following:

Switch to grass-fed operations

· Decreases soil erosion/cattle waste fertilizes soil

Eat lower on food chain/eat plant matter rather than beef

· Maintains or increases biodiversity or habitat as uses less land for equivalent calories

Plant buffers of vegetation

· Maintains or increases biodiversity or habitat as creates new habitat

Construct physical barriers/retention ponds

· Decreases soil erosion

The response justifies the solution with an additional environmental benefit, such as one of the following:

Switch to grass-fed operations

· Decreases soil erosion/cattle waste fertilizes soil

Eat lower on food chain/eat plant matter rather than beef

· Maintains or increases biodiversity or habitat as uses less land for equivalent calories

Plant buffers of vegetation

· Maintains or increases biodiversity or habitat as creates new habitat

Construct physical barriers/retention ponds

· Decreases soil erosion

title: Part (b)(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain the process during which landfill gas is burned to produce electricity, such as any of the following.

· Burning landfill gas heats water to produce steam, which turns a turbine, which spins a generator to produce electricity

· Burning landfill gas directly turns a turbine, which spins a generator to produce electricity.

· Methane is separated from landfill gas to produce higher BTU gas. Burning methane directly turns a turbine, which spins a generator to produce electricity.

The response explains the process during which landfill gas is burned to produce electricity, such as one of the following.

· Burning landfill gas heats water to produce steam, which turns a turbine, which spins a generator to produce electricity

· Burning landfill gas directly turns a turbine, which spins a generator to produce electricity.

· Methane is separated from landfill gas to produce higher BTU gas. Burning methane directly turns a turbine, which spins a generator to produce electricity.
